channel.title: [New Langauge] Microsoft Small Basic
channel.description:
http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/devlabs/cc950524.aspx
The first trials were successfully done with several [b]middle school children, most of them children of workers at Microsoft[/b].
Small Basic was also successfully tested using a hands-on lab approach to a group of 25 high school girls.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Small_Basic

item.title: [New Langauge] Microsoft Small Basic
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Frell:

No, PS network is for poor people.

QFT! The XBox 360 probably costs more than the PS3 if you include the cost of a wireless adapter and a year’s subscription to XBL(because lets face it, this gen is going to last 3-4 more years, and none of us have anything better to do than play games).

atrox_:

So how many people play PSN, 100… 200 max?

Very good.

At 10PM(GMT), COD5 usually has about 100k players on PS3, a friend said at the same time there were about 200k players on 360, considering the PS3 is selling more in Europe, and the 360 more in America, this is about right.

On my PS3, the only game I have trouble finding matches with is COD5’s Nazi Zombies. Finding a match in any other game I have on my PS3 isn’t an issue.

But back to the original topic, it just looks like another copy of VB. If school’s wanted to teach their students something useful, they should teach them C#, Java, C++ or any other language that isn’t some form of BASIC.

Read full topic

item.title: [New Langauge] Microsoft Small Basic
item.dc:creator: @atrox atrox_
item.description:
@atrox wrote:

[quote=“sanga282, post:17, topic:264687”][quote author=Frell link=topic=349488.msg2690198#msg2690198 date=1235922811]

The first time you connect your 360 to the net they give you a free 1 month of live.

And xbox live silver membership is free. You can still chat with your friends and send/receive messages and such, you just can’t play against people online.
[/quote]Or join parties…

Or have any fun. Thats Why PS Network > Xbox Live!

No, PS network is for poor people.

by that standard then so is linux…
jsut because its free doesnt mean its for poor people. XBL is an overpriced laggy shitstick ran by capitalists. PSN on the other hand is fast, fun and efficient. The benefit of it is that it is free why should you pay extra to game over the internet its not right.[/quote]
So how many people play PSN, 100… 200 max?

Read full topic

item.description:
@Cruzer wrote:

GraphicsWindow.BackgroundColor = "Black" For i = 1 To 1000 GraphicsWindow.BrushColor = GraphicsWindow.GetRandomColor() x = Math.GetRandomNumber(800) y = Math.GetRandomNumber(600) GraphicsWindow.FillEllipse(x, y, 10, 10) EndFor

i am proffesionals coder now

Read full topic

item.title: [New Langauge] Microsoft Small Basic
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Cain_”][quote author=T4_ link=topic=349488.msg2686437#msg2686437 date=1235695129]
Given the fact the language was made by Microsoft, it can’t be good or useful.

Also,

TextWindow.WriteLine("Hello World")

Seems a little complex for a language aimed for youngsters. (Not that it is; but if it aimed for novices, the syntax should be easier.)

Write("Hello World")

Would have been easier.
[/quote]

Maybe they want to teach object orientation? And Write(“Hello World”) may be a bit vague, ie it could “Write” to stdout or a window ?[/quote]

Well, that’s true - but if the main strategy of the project was to provide basic programming skills to younger people, I think a language with similar syntax to BASIC would be better.

Read full topic

item.title: [New Langauge] Microsoft Small Basic
item.dc:creator: @magekal magekal
item.description:
@magekal wrote:

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/devlabs/cc950524.aspx

The first trials were successfully done with several middle school children, most of them children of workers at Microsoft.

Small Basic was also successfully tested using a hands-on lab approach to a group of 25 high school girls.

en.wikipedia.org

Microsoft Small Basic

Microsoft Small Basic is a programming language and associated IDE. It is Microsoft's simplified variant of the BASIC programming language, intended as an easy programming language for beginners. The associated IDE provides a simplified programming environment with functionality such as syntax highlighting, intelligent code completion, and in-editor documentation access. The language has only 14 keywords. Microsoft announced Small Basic in October 2008, and released the first stable version for ...

Read full topic
